div.p:
Thank you dear kind Mrs. Lockhart for
writing to me and believing as well you may
in the interest I take in all that concerns
you I am glad the voyage & journey is so
well over for you and your boy and con-
gratulate congratulate you with all my heart on your
finding Sir Walter Scott so much better -
Your being at Abbotsford will be the best
possible cordial for him and one which
his physicians will not need to restrain
him in the use of - We were very anxious
to know your opinion of him and it has
relieved me from a great anxiety. I think
your influence will be of the greatest use
as well as pleasure to him, for you will
be able with the nice touch of kindness to
get him to mind whatever is essential to
his health and you will never plague with
any useless restrictions - Besides you will
raise his spirits in a way which no one
else can - he is so excessively fond of you &
you have in your favor all the early associations of feeling
which are so powerful, in illness - I think
I hear you now playing on the harp and singing

on the harp to him the Bonnie house of Airly
and I see the fire lighting in his eyes
- I wish I could be really with you but
Alas! Alas! that is impossible - absolutely
impossible - my fate is fixed and to
Ire-
=land Ireland
I must return straight - But I
shall live in hopes of visiting Scotland
next year and of seeing your dear
father perfectly restored to health - that
health for which millions are so anxi-
ous anxious he should long enjoy - for their
enjoyment - (and among those millions
it is a bold word - but I really believe
there is not one out of his own circle
of family & own old friends that has
a more sincere affection & deeper gra-
titude gratitude to him than i have - Give my
plain love to him & God bless him! -

I have been here this week with
thy good friend Mr. Malthus ( and others
- I have heard of nothing of London news
but that Mr. Robert Grant has been returned
for Norwich after a vexatious opposition
which obliged him to put off a pleasant
dinner party he had made for me & now

that it is re-fixed for the 18th. he tells me that
he is in fear of being called away again to
the elections for Inverness shire.

As far as I heard before I left Town
ministry are now afraid of having
too great a majority for the bill - the
bill and nothing but the bill - that
is to say that they fear they may not
have it in their power to make any
salutary modifications in committees
- And too much of a good thing &c -

I hear the cuckoo and see the flowers
and smell new mown grass at this
instant and am perfectly happy &
stupid - Fanny is at this moment engaged with an inquest of naturalists by the side of a pond settling whether certain tadpoles are to be or not to be toads or frogs - as we Irish know nothing of toads it is argued that Fanny must by the mode of exclusion be the best judge of this case Verdict has just been pronounced Frogs is better than when
you saw her - much refreshed by quiet
and country air - Back in a few minutes
the carriage will be at the door to carry
us back again to the whirl of London
I think Sir Walter judges very rightly
in not coming to Town till he is quite
strong for it requires the strength of Hercules
to lead a London life - and
Mr Lockhart will
say Pooh! Pooh! not at all - I know he
is with you & I give you joy of that & pray

give my love to him - How very tenderly
& kindly B Halls book is reviewed in the
Quarterly - How thankful he must be - ought
to be I mean -

Remember me very kindly to Miss Scott
& tell her I hope to see her next year
bright Beatrice -

Fanny loves you dear Mrs.
Lockhart - who can help it that has either
heart or head
